bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Charles W. Stiles, February 13, 1922

div1.p: [Carter] asks Stiles if the cattle fever tick is becoming acclimated to colder climates.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Charles W. Stiles, February 13, 1922
div1.opener:
I. H. B.
(Book) Stiles
2121 California St. N. W.
, D. C.
February 13, 1922.
/LC
Assistant Surgeon General Charles Wardell Stiles,
Hygienic Laboratory, U. S. Public Health Service,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Doctor Stiles:
div1.p:
Years ago, in reading of the Texas cattle fever. I came across
a lot of data. which led the writer--Billings I think, but I am not
sure of that, to state that the disease was becoming permanently en-
demic further north than it had been in previous years.

Do you know anything that would make you think that the vector
tick, with the unpronouncable name, has been able to acclimate it-
self to a greater degree of cold than it could endure--say--50 or
100 years ago?
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General. (On Waiting Orders)
Address
2121 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
